semantic_title: Coding Guidelines for Death NOS (Not Otherwise Specified)
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 18. Chapter 18: Symptoms, signs, and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings > h. Death NOS

content.full_text: Code R99, Ill-defined and unknown cause of mortality, is only for use in the very limited circumstance when a patient who has already died is brought into an emergency department or other healthcare facility and is pronounced dead upon arrival. It does not represent the discharge disposition of death. (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)
content.summary: Specific guidelines for the very limited use of code R99 for ill-defined mortality, restricted to patients pronounced dead upon arrival (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)
key_concepts: Very limited use circumstances (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)
Dead on arrival scenarios (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)
Not for discharge disposition (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code R99 is only for use in the very limited circumstance when a patient who has already died is brought into an emergency department or other healthcare facility and is pronounced dead upon arrival (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)
detailed_rules.explanation: This code has extremely restricted use for dead-on-arrival situations only (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)
common_applications: Dead on arrival to emergency department

detailed_rules.rule_text: It does not represent the discharge disposition of death (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)
detailed_rules.explanation: R99 is not used to indicate that a patient died during the encounter (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Verify patient was already deceased upon arrival
Step 2: Confirm patient was pronounced dead upon arrival
Step 3: Ensure this is not a discharge disposition scenario
Step 4: Apply R99 only if all criteria met

specific_codes.description: Ill-defined and unknown cause of mortality - only for dead on arrival cases (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)
specific_codes.context: Very limited use for patients pronounced dead upon arrival

breakdown.R99: Ill-defined and unknown cause of mortality

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient brought to ED by EMS, already deceased, pronounced dead upon arrival
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient found unresponsive at home, no pulse, brought to ED by EMS, pronounced dead upon arrival
step_by_step: Step 1: Verify patient was deceased before arrival
Step 2: Confirm pronounced dead upon arrival

correct_coding.rationale: Meets criteria for very limited use of R99 for dead on arrival (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)

incorrect_coding.rationale: R99 does not represent discharge disposition of death
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using R99 for patients who die during hospitalization

warnings: R99 has very limited use - only for dead on arrival cases (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)
Do not use R99 for discharge disposition of death (Evidence: pg no: 77, L52)
best_practices: Verify patient was already deceased before facility arrival
common_mistakes: Using R99 for patients who die during hospitalization
tips: This code is rarely used due to its very specific criteria
implementation_notes: Primarily used in emergency department settings
